In accordance with decree n ° 2020-884 of July 17, 2020, the wearing of a mask has become compulsory in closed places welcoming the public.    In addition, decree n ° 2020-944 of July 30, 2020 provides for the possibility for the prefects, when the local epidemic situation requires it, to extend the obligation to wear a mask to all relevant places , that is to say - also say public space.  This is an essential protection measure, especially in closed environments or when there is a high population density (market, busy street, etc.). In addition to barrier gestures (hand washing, physical distancing), it is the mask that filters the droplets from sneezing, coughing, or even prolonged discussion.  https://web.archive.org/save/https://www.gouvernement.fr/en/coronavirus-covid-19
No policy change

Take off your mask - masks are compulsory in all enclosed public spaces in France while around 400 local authorities - which includes all the major cities - have also made masks compulsory in the street.      https://web.archive.org/web/20201222023746/https://www.thelocal.fr/20201217/what-can-you-do-in-france-over-christmas-and-new-year-under-covid-19-rules

No availability yet but plans in place to start vaccination in January. Vaccination will be rolled out in three phases:    Phase 1: January 2021 – elderly care home residents, and residence staff who are at risk of developing severe illness (about one million people)  Phase 2: February 2021 -  people who are at risk of developing severe illness, and health care workers – about 14 million people.  Phase 3: spring 2021 – availability for the entire population, although still prioritized e.g. by age.  Vaccination will be free and voluntary.    https://archive.vn/aLCoS
PARIS (Reuters) - France will start its COVID-19 vaccination programme next Sunday, Health Minister Olivier Veran wrote on his Twitter feed.  https://archive.vn/HrrMw

14. December 2020, The Government with new measures for Christmas    Retailers at Christmas: Businesses should ensure that hand sanitiser is readily available and that stores are kept clean. Signs should be clearly displayed to help customers keep to the recommendations. Staff should use protective gear where necessary. Retailers can help by making face masks available for customers. If retailers cannot limit the number of customers so that the recommended distances can be maintained, then both customers and staff are advised to wear face masks.      https://web.archive.org/web/20201214155432/https://corona.fo/news/748/the-government-with-new-measures-for-christmas?_l=en

14. December 2020, The Government with new measures for Christmas    · Sport: All indoor sporting events should be held without spectators. This applies to both adult and children’s competitions. Coaches and assistants can be present during matches.    · Schools and daycare centres are advised not to hold larger events to which people from outside the institution are usually invited. This includes Christmas celebrations which would normally be attended by parents and other family members. Christmas church services for school pupils and preschool children should not be organised as usual this year      https://web.archive.org/web/20201214155432/https://corona.fo/news/748/the-government-with-new-measures-for-christmas?_l=en

14. December 2020, The Government with new measures for Christmas    · Schools and daycare centres are advised not to hold larger events to which people from outside the institution are usually invited. This includes Christmas celebrations which would normally be attended by parents and other family members. Christmas church services for school pupils and preschool children should not be organised as usual this year.    · Christmas shopping: Special emphasis should be placed on social distancing hand and hygiene and. It is advisable that only one person in the household does the shopping, rather than going several together. It is also advisable to go shopping when there are fewer people.  Face masks are recommended when a lot of people are in a shop. If you have come to the Faroe Islands from abroad, you should not go shopping at all until you have received a negative result from the test that you should take 6 days after arrival.      https://web.archive.org/web/20201214155432/https://corona.fo/news/748/the-government-with-new-measures-for-christmas?_l=en

3rd Dec 2020, Mandatory border testing continues until 31 March. This strategy has played an important role in limiting the spread of the virus; however, the commission is keen to point out that testing travellers are only part of the solution.    Social distancing, good hygiene, staying at home if any symptoms appear and taking a follow-up test on day six after arriving from abroad remain crucial in the fight against Covid-19, says the epidemic commission.    https://web.archive.org/web/20201208143045/https://corona.fo/news/734/mandatory-border-testing-continues-until-31-march?_l=en

11. December 2020, Test center opening hours are scheduled. Testing is free of charge. Currently UK is offering the Pfizer vaccine to "frontline staff, those over 80, and care home workers" from 50 hospitals. It expects to begin vaccinating all care home residents in 2 weeks," but is not doing so yet. Vaccines will be distributed evenly across the 4 nations of the UK. The UK has ordered 40m doses of this vaccine, and has 880,000 on hand https://web.archive.org/web/20201208073322/https://www.bbc.com/news/health-55045639  UK policy for COVID Vaccines in England given by Public Health England "Green Book" https://web.archive.org/web/20201208072743/https://assets.publishing.service.gov.uk/government/uploads/system/uploads/attachment_data/file/941450/Greenbook_chapter_14a_v2.pdf

With a few exceptions, Georgia remains closed to foreign travelers. The entry ban for foreign citizens applies to air, land, and sea borders, including foreign citizens who are legal residents of Georgia, or have been living and working in Georgia, or own property or business. Also, there are health screening procedures in place at airports and other ports of entry.  Link: https://archive.fo/wip/LILgr

Face masks must be worn in all enclosed public spaces, including taxis and public transportation. Violators of face musk rules are subject to a 20 GEL (about 6 USD) fine. From 7 December 2020 through 14 December 2020, all schools (including higher education institutions) are physically closed.    https://web.archive.org/web/20201209182307/https://covid19.gov.gr/leitourgia-scholeion-pasis-fysis-ekpaideftikon-domon-aei-kai-choron-latreias-gia-to-diastima-apo-ti-deftera-7-dekemvriou-2020-kai-ora-600-eos-kai-ti-deftera-14-dekemvriou-2020-kai-ora-600-2/

Greek authorities have re-imposed a lockdown through January 7, 2021 to combat the spread of COVID-19. Authorities announced 24-hour movement restrictions, mandatory three day quarantine for travelers arriving from abroad, an expanded nighttime curfew, suspension of many business and entertainment operations, prohibition of gatherings, restrictions of restaurant operations to delivery/carry-out only, and restrictions on travel between regions in Greece.   https://web.archive.org/web/*/https://gr.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

Some non-essential sectors remain open during the current lockdown, which is in effect until 14 December 2020 nationwide.    Seasonal shops, selling only Christmas items, reopened on Monday 7 December for a few days. By the end of the week, the government will make further decisions on the operation of churches, hair salons and the retail sector, Petsas said.    https://web.archive.org/web/20201209185340if_/https://www.reuters.com/article/idUSKBN28H1GL

Greek authorities have re-imposed a lockdown through January 7, 2021 to combat the spread of COVID-19. Authorities announced 24-hour movement restrictions, mandatory three day quarantine for travelers arriving from abroad, an expanded nighttime curfew, suspension of many business and entertainment operations, prohibition of gatherings, restrictions of restaurant operations to delivery/carry-out only, and restrictions on travel between regions in Greece.   https://web.archive.org/web/*/https://gr.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/    No more than nine people (from two households) should gather in the same house, in order to avoid overcrowding.  https://web.archive.org/web/*/https://greekcitytimes.com/2020/12/14/christmas-covid19-rules-greece/
No change in policy.

Is public transportation operating? Yes  Masks are required while using public transportation and taxis. Taxis are limited to one passenger, except for minor children.  https://web.archive.org/web/*/https://gr.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/
No change in policy.

Movement Restrictions:  Is a curfew in place? Yes  A nationwide lockdown is in effect 24 hours per day through January 7, 2021.  A nighttime curfew is additionally in effect from 10:00pm to 5:00am.  In general, travel outside the home should be avoided, but is permitted for work and for the following reasons between the hours of 5:00am and 10:00pm:  For health reasons;  To buy essential supplies if delivery is not possible in time;  Essential banking or urgent appointments for public services (e.g., electricity);  To help people in need. Transfer to/from workplace of a spouse or first-degree relative. Transfer of a minor to/from school (with a certificate from the school);  Attending a ceremony (e.g., funeral). Travel to exercise visitation rights;  Movements near one’s residence for physical exercise, or care of pets or strays  https://web.archive.org/web/*/https://gr.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/    All individuals residing in Greece will be required to send an SMS text message to 13033 in order to obtain permission to leave their homes during the lockdown.    The SMS to 13033 should be formatted as follows: X (one of the digits 1-6 corresponding to the activities below), name, surname and address. https://web.archive.org/web/*/https://greekcitytimes.com/2020/12/14/christmas-covid19-rules-greece/
No change in policy.

Are there restrictions on intercity or interstate travel? Yes  As of November 7, 2020,  travel between other regions in Greece is allowed only for health reasons, business, family reunification, or to return to one’s place of permanent residence and requires declaration as described at forma.gov.gr/en.  https://web.archive.org/web/*/https://gr.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/
No change in policy.

Are U.S. citizens permitted to enter? No  Greece will currently only allow EU citizens, EU residents, and residents of certain other specific countries to enter. The United States is not one of those countries.  U.S. citizens traveling to Greece will not be permitted to enter unless they meet one of only a few narrow exceptions detailed in the Greek Embassy’s information on entrance into the European Union/Schengen Area.  There is no projected date when entry will be permitted.  A long visit in a third country will not help you get around EU restrictions.  https://web.archive.org/web/*/https://gr.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/    Those entering Greece from abroad between December 18 and January 7 must observe a mandatory three-day quarantine. https://web.archive.org/web/*/https://greekcitytimes.com/2020/12/14/christmas-covid19-rules-greece/
No change in policy.

Noting that on 30 November, the government imposed price caps of 40 euros ($48) for regular swab tests and 10 euros ($12) for rapid tests on coronavirus tests at private labs, cutting current rates at most labs by more than half.    In response, the Panhellenic Medical Association said that the measure would force many independent labs to stop providing COVID-19 tests because they would be too costly for them, putting additional pressure on the state-run health service.    https://web.archive.org/web/20201209205053/https://apnews.com/article/europe-coronavirus-pandemic-greece-cc66d79f55b050c97059a1de6ce104dd

COVID-19 tests are available at many major hospitals in Greece, as well as the Athens Eleftherios Venizelos Airport (at Arrivals level between entrances 2-3). Testing is paid by the individual being tested.  The average cost for COVID-19 testing is 100-120 euros. Patients needing COVID-19 tests or exhibiting possible symptoms may contact the COVID-19 hotline at 1135 for guidance on testing and referral for medical care.  https://web.archive.org/web/*/https://gr.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/
No change in policy.

Vaccines are not yet being administered, but there is a government-funded policy in place:    Greek Prime Minister Kyriakos Mitsotakis met with advisors and government ministers virtually on Saturday 5 December 20202 in order to discuss the country’s Covid-19 vaccination plan.    Reportedly, vaccinations will begin in January, with healthcare workers having priority. Greeks will be able to make appointments to receive the free shot at one of the country’s 1,018 vaccination centers that are currently being created in order to best distribute the vaccine to as many people as possible.    https://web.archive.org/web/20201209210724/https://greece.greekreporter.com/2020/12/05/greece-to-begin-covid-19-vaccinations-in-january-1383-new-cases-saturday/
No noted updates  https://web.archive.org/web/*/https://gr.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

As above: no recommended closure but certainly 'all schools open with alterations resulting in significant differences compared to usual.'   'Sick students, teachers and other staff must stay home. Source:  http://web.archive.org/web/20201221145713/https://nun.gl/emner/borgere/coronavirus_emne/til_skoler?sc_lang=da

No guidance to close. Only suggestion is that those who have to work in the home of others must continue to follow covid guidance as in public space.    Source:  https://web.archive.org/web/20201221150119/https://nun.gl/emner/borgere/coronavirus_emne/erhvervspakke_til_erhverv/vejledning_til_haandvaerks?sc_lang=da

No change found.  The latest update remains that there is an executive order in place, until and including the 31st January 2021, which states:  “It is possible to hold public events within current municipal boundaries with certain restrictions. It is the organizer's responsibility to ensure that there is no participation from people from other municipalities, or that this is encouraged.  Courses can still be run with external teachers, as long as the participants are from the same municipality.”  “There must be a maximum of 100 people for an indoor event, provided that the rules on occupancy in the room itself of a maximum of 50% of what is allowed are also complied with. For outdoor events, there can be a maximum of 250 people.”    Source:  https://web.archive.org/web/20201221150605/https://nun.gl/emner/borgere/coronavirus_emne/forsamlinger_i_groenland?sc_lang=da

Indoor events must have a maximum of 100 and outdoor 250 (if all participants from the same municipality).    Source:  https://web.archive.org/web/20201221150605/https://nun.gl/emner/borgere/coronavirus_emne/forsamlinger_i_groenland?sc_lang=da

Updated restrictions to forbid travel to/from Denmark as well as all other regions. 'Based on the health professional recommendations and forecasts for potential spread of infection in society, the Naalakkersuisut has actively looked at reducing the number of travellers over Christmas and the New Year... The departures to and from Denmark on 21 and 22 December will be canceled as well as associated domestic connections.' Possibly extended until January 17th.    Source:  https://web.archive.org/web/20201221143722/https://naalakkersuisut.gl/da/Naalakkersuisut/Nyheder/2020/12/0212_lukning_aflysning

On December 19, economic protections are extended until 01 July.  According to this, the moratorium on loan repayments for families and businesses will be extended unchanged for six months until 1 July. The moratorium will be automatically extended, only those who want to repay their loan despite the moratorium will have to visit their bank, the Prime Minister said.  It also announced that businesses forced to close temporarily as a a cause of disease measures would be supported by the government in December and January by waived and taking over two-thirds of wage costs. In addition to catering, hotels and tourism, the remission of contributions and wage subsidies will be extended to private bus companies that are forced to take a break.  Viktor Orban also said that business taxes for small and medium-sized enterprises and sole proprietors will be cut by half from 1 January. These businesses account for the most jobs and are the most vulnerable during the epidemic, he justified the measure, adding that municipalities of less than 25,000 inhabitants will receive support from the government and the financial situation of larger municipalities will be reviewed individually.  The fourth decision is to help families with children and children with a reduced home improvement loan of up to HUF 6 million with a maximum interest rate of 3 percent. Of this, HUF 3 million is a non-refundable grant, which can be used at the end of the renovation and automatically reduces the amount of the loan, the Prime Minister explained.    https://web.archive.org/web/20201219210422/https://koronavirus.gov.hu/cikkek/orban-viktor-kormany-gazdasagvedelmi-akcioterv-kiegesziteserol-rendelkezett

Although a vaccine is still not available, the Russian vaccine and its documentation are being examined, and the documentation of the Chinese vaccine will soon arrive in Hungary.     https://archive.vn/y5lyf

On 18 December, it was announced that vaccinations against the coronavirus can begin on 27 or 28 December, in the first round a sufficient amount will arrive in Hungary for 35,000 people, and health workers will be vaccinated in the first place, Prime Minister Viktor Orban announced on Kossuth radio's Good Morning, Hungary! on his show. Vaccination will be voluntary and free of charge.    https://web.archive.org/web/20201219205730/https://koronavirus.gov.hu/cikkek/orban-december-27-28-kezdodhetnek-az-elso-oltasok

From 4th December in Ireland restaurants and pubs operating as restaurants (serving a substantial meal) can open for indoor dining with additional restrictions, with a maximum of 6 people per table. All retail shops and shopping centres can open. All services such as hairdressers, beauticians, barbers and opticians can open with strict adherence to sectoral guidance on protective measures.    https://web.archive.org/web/20201214192520/https://www.gov.ie/en/publication/ad569-level-3/

Organised events can take place in Ireland as long as these are controlled environments with a named event organiser, owner or manager.  Gatherings of up to 15 people can take place. Face coverings are recommended in busy or crowded areas.     https://web.archive.org/web/20201214192520/https://www.gov.ie/en/publication/ad569-level-3/
From 4th December public transport capacity limited to 50%.    https://web.archive.org/web/20201214192520/https://www.gov.ie/en/publication/ad569-level-3/

Recommended to stay in your county apart from work, education, medical and other essential purposes, if appropriate.    https://web.archive.org/web/20201214192520/https://www.gov.ie/en/publication/ad569-level-3/

On 22 December the Irish Government extended its ban on flights and passenger ferry journeys from Great Britain until at least 31 December. This applies to people in Great Britain regardless of nationality. Ferry crossings from Great Britain to Ireland will continue for freight, including accompanied freight, but not passengers, although ferry journeys from Ireland to Great Britain are open to both freight and passengers.    https://web.archive.org/web/20201228200145/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/ireland/entry-requirements

The Irish Government announced additional flexibility for self-employed workers on the scheme was announced. Self-employed people in receipt of the PUP who are looking to restart their business can now earn up to €960 over an 8 week period, while retaining their full PUP entitlement. This is an increase from the €480 previously allowed over a 4 week period and comes following engagement across a number of sectors.    https://web.archive.org/web/20201214193900/https://www.gov.ie/en/publication/43e6e-briefing-on-the-governments-response-to-covid-19-friday-11-december-2020/

Restrictions have been updated although coding remains the same.  Performing arts, cinema theatres and other cultural events may have up to 30 persons on stage, i.e. during rehearsals and shows. Up to 50 seated guests may be accommodated. Such guests must wear face masks. In addition, 100 children born in 2005 or later may be accommodated. Seats are to be numbered and labelled with the name of the guest. Neither breaks nor alcohol sales are permitted.  Restaurants may be open until 22:00 on all days but must comply with the 15-person limit rule and the 2-metre proximity limit between unrelated persons. Take-away meals may be served after 22:00.  Pharmacies, grocery stores and other stores may accept 5 persons for each 10 m2 of space and may have up to 100 customers in their premises, as long as it is possible to ensure at least 2 metres between persons who are unrelated.    Swimming pools are open and may accept up to 50% of their maximum number of guests according to their operating permit.    Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20201213162115/https://www.covid.is/sub-categories/what-is-ban-on-public-events

Further tightening of restrictions regarding the ongoing lockdown declared early November:    Primary, pre-secondary and secondary education will be provided remotely, except special needs schools and special needs classes in general education schools following the programmes of primary, pre-secondary, individualised primary and pre-secondary education, and secondary education, programmes of development of social skills;    Pre-school, pre-primary education will be provided following the conditions laid down by the Commander of Operations’ decision, in-person pre-school and pre-primary education is recommended only for those children whose parents (adoptive parents or guardians) have no possibilities of working remotely.    https://web.archive.org/web/20201228144835/https://koronastop.lrv.lt/en/news/covid-19-related-restrictions-updated-on-23-december-2020

Update on 2nd of December:    "Government approves tighter lockdown rules.    The adverse epidemic coronavirus (COVID-19) situation in Lithuania has necessitated further tightening of the lockdown rules by restricting the size of gatherings, banning the operation of temporary vendors in malls and supermarkets. It has also been recommended to discontinue short-term sales promotion measures to bring down visitor flows.    The Government has agreed to ban the operation of temporary vendors in shops, supermarkets and points of service, where sales are not made in physically separated premises but in common areas and passageways of malls and supermarkets. Exceptions apply to selling foodstuffs, pyrotechnic items and also to fixed vending stalls."    https://web.archive.org/web/20201210091436/https://koronastop.lrv.lt/en/news/government-approves-tighter-lockdown-rules

Update on 2nd of December (coming into force on Wednesday, December 9):    "Government approves tighter lockdown rules.    The adverse epidemic coronavirus (COVID-19) situation in Lithuania has necessitated further tightening of the lockdown rules by restricting the size of gatherings, banning the operation of temporary vendors in malls and supermarkets. It has also been recommended to discontinue short-term sales promotion measures to bring down visitor flows.    The Government has agreed to ban the operation of temporary vendors in shops, supermarkets and points of service, where sales are not made in physically separated premises but in common areas and passageways of malls and supermarkets. Exceptions apply to selling foodstuffs, pyrotechnic items and also to fixed vending stalls."    https://web.archive.org/web/20201210091436/https://koronastop.lrv.lt/en/news/government-approves-tighter-lockdown-rules

Further tightening of restrictions regarding the ongoing lockdown declared early November:    State and municipal institutions and bodies and state and municipal enterprises and the private sector will organise work and provide customer services remotely, except where relevant functions (work) have to be performed at the workplace, while ensuring conditions laid down by the State Commander of National Emergency Operations for the management of the flow of people, safe physical distance, and other key requirements for public health safety, hygiene, and the provision of persons with necessary personal protective equipment    Stores, including those in shopping and/or entertainment centres, marketplaces and other public points of sale will be closed except:    -stores (including those in shopping and/or entertainment centres), whose main business is the retail of food, veterinary, animal feed, pharmacy, optical goods and orthopedic technical devices;  -selling food in marketplaces and public points of sale;  -remote commerce (by internet or other means of communication), where goods are delivered to natural and legal persons or collected at collection points;  -funeral stores;  -outdoor trade in Christmas trees and other festive trees.    Stores that remain open will be required to:    ensure 15 sq. m. of retail space per visitor or serve only one visitor at a time and ensure other conditions laid down by the State Commander of National Emergency Operations.    https://web.archive.org/web/20201228144835/https://koronastop.lrv.lt/en/news/covid-19-related-restrictions-updated-on-23-december-2020

There will be no indoor or outdoor commercial or non-commercial cultural, entertainment, sporting events, celebrations, fairs, festivals or other mass gatherings arranged in public locations of a certain duration at a scheduled time except:    high-performance sporting events without spectators;  funerals attended by maximum 10 persons except family and/or household members and persons providing funeral services.    https://web.archive.org/web/20201228144835/https://koronastop.lrv.lt/en/news/covid-19-related-restrictions-updated-on-23-december-2020

With growing outbreaks in LTC, in December 2020 MOH has adjusted the procedure for preventive testing health and social care facilities. Health and social care providers employing more than 10 staff who have contact with patients have to test between 10% and 20% of employees weekly.    https://web.archive.org/web/20201228152204/https://www.covid19healthsystem.org/countries/lithuania/livinghit.aspx?Section=1.5+Testing&Type=Section

Currently, the contact tracing system in Lithuania is overwhelmed. On 3rd December, newly elected Prime Minister Ingrida Simonyte told that NVSC failed to do contact tracing for all positve cases. Moreover, the newly elected Minister of Health Arunas Dulkys on 12th December told that the priority at the time was that NVSC could complete contact tracing for all cases within 48 hours after positive test result, indicating that it is not currently done.    Link: https://web.archive.org/web/20201212143139/https://www.lrt.lt/naujienos/lietuvoje/2/1290792/simonyte-kritikuoja-nvsc-del-nepasiruosimo-vasara-jei-istinka-koma-nuo-200-nauju-atveju-akivaizdu-kazkas-neveikia  https://web.archive.org/web/20201212143341/https://www.lrt.lt/naujienos/lietuvoje/2/1296629/dulkys-tikina-kaledoms-atsipalaiduoti-negalima-nereiketu-del-to-apgaudineti-saves

"The first groups to be vaccinated would include our [Lithuania’s] medics, people in care homes, people in risk groups”, said Sinkevicius (Lithuania’s European Commissioner).    https://web.archive.org/web/20201210094732/https://www.lrt.lt/en/news-in-english/19/1293325/lithuania-may-receive-covid-vaccine-in-3-4-weeks-says-european-commissioner-sinkevicius

Lithuania started vaccinations against COVID-19 on 27th of December:    "Lithuania on Saturday started to vaccinate its medical workers against the coronavirus in a coordinated push by the European Union against the global pandemic.  Nijole Ramonaite, a nurse at Vilnius University Hospital Santaros Klinikos, was the first person in the country inoculated by the vaccine produced by Pfizer and BionTech.  Vaccination was launched in hospitals in Vilnius, Kaunas, Klaipeda, Siauliai and Panevezys simultaneously at 8:00 a.m. on Sunday."  https://web.archive.org/web/20201228154724/https://www.baltictimes.com/lithuania_starts_vaccinations_against_covid-19/    Regarding strategy:  Acting Health Minister Aurelijus Veryga said that medics and at-risk people in the country would be vaccinated from the coronavirus first. If a sufficient amount of vaccines is delivered to Lithuania, mass vaccination of the population could start in February or March, according to Veryga.    https://web.archive.org/web/20201228154743/https://www.lrt.lt/en/news-in-english/19/1296189/most-people-in-lithuania-to-receive-vaccines-by-mid-summer-says-president

The first groups that will benefit from this vaccine are the elderly, identified as people that are 65 years or more, and the healthcare workers.     https://web.archive.org/web/20201213172111/https://www.ecdc.europa.eu/sites/default/files/documents/Overview-of-EU_EEA-UK-vaccination-deployment-plans.pdf

On 1 December 2020, the Cabinet of Ministers extended the emergency situation introducing stricter safety measures and restriction until January 11, 2021.     http://web.archive.org/web/20201207030317/https://mk.gov.lv/en/aktualitates/emergency-situation-has-been-extended-until-11-january-introducing-stricter-safety    The on-site study process shall take place only in kindergartens and from grade 1 to grade 4. An area of at least 3 square meters per pupil must be provided. From 3 December, kindergarten employees shall wear masks at all times. From 4 January, both pupils and teachers shall wear masks during lessons and outside the learning process at schools.  The completion of higher education, adult continuous vocational training, vocational in-service training, and non-formal education programs shall be held only remotely. On the other hand, practical skills that cannot be acquired remotely can be acquired in person only individually - one teacher with one student.  The practical parts of interest education can take place in person only individually. Practices of choirs and wind instruments are not allowed in person.
No change to previous policy (running until 11th January)

On 1 December 2020, the Cabinet of Ministers extended the emergency situation introducing stricter safety measures and restriction until January 11, 2021.   http://web.archive.org/web/20201207030317/https://mk.gov.lv/en/aktualitates/emergency-situation-has-been-extended-until-11-january-introducing-stricter-safety  rom 3 December, 15 square meters per visitor must be provided in shops and service points. Information on the number of people allowed must be clearly visible at the entrance. Economic service providers, shops and event organizers must ensure that people who do not wear a face mask or do it incorrectly are not allowed on the premises and services are not provided to those who do not comply with epidemiological safety requirements.  All shops and the shopping centers, regardless of the total sales area, shall be open on weekdays as usual. However, only pharmacies, including veterinary pharmacies, may operate on Saturdays, Sundays, and public holidays, while only groceries (except alcohol and cigarettes), hygiene products and fuel may be sold in shops. On weekdays, everyone works with the same quadrature constraints. On Saturdays, Sundays and public holidays, sales points may not be open, except - pharmacies (including veterinary) and shops selling food (except alcohol and cigarettes), hygiene products, fuel. Subject to epidemiological safety measures, beauty care providers - hairdressing and manicure service providers - may operate. Libraries are allowed on site to loan out books and, subject to epidemiological security measures, museums are still available to visitors.
No change to previous policy (running until 11th January)
No change to previous policy (running until 6th December by latest legislation).

On 1 December 2020, the Cabinet of Ministers extended the emergency situation introducing stricter safety measures and restriction until January 11, 2021.   http://web.archive.org/web/20201207030317/https://mk.gov.lv/en/aktualitates/emergency-situation-has-been-extended-until-11-january-introducing-stricter-safety  As of 3 December, principle 2 + 2 shall be observed by everyone in Latvia in their daily routine - two meters, two people. So, a distance of two meters must be observed and meetings must be limited to two people. Until 11 January, operation of all cultural sites, exhibitions, as well as fairs, including Christmas markets, shall be prohibited. In the meantime, no more than 20% of the maximum number of people may be present at the same time in places of religious activity.  Organized meetings, pickets and marches are still allowed, but a maximum of 25 people is allowed to attend, subject to epidemiological safety requirements.
No change to previous policy (running until 11th January)
No change to previous policy (running until 6th December by latest legislation).

On 1 December 2020, the Cabinet of Ministers extended the emergency situation introducing stricter safety measures and restriction until January 11, 2021.   http://web.archive.org/web/20201207030317/https://mk.gov.lv/en/aktualitates/emergency-situation-has-been-extended-until-11-january-introducing-stricter-safety  On 1 December 2020, the Cabinet of Ministers extended the emergency situation introducing stricter safety measures and restriction until January 11, 2021.   http://web.archive.org/web/20201207030317/https://mk.gov.lv/en/aktualitates/emergency-situation-has-been-extended-until-11-january-introducing-stricter-safety    As of 3 December, principle 2 + 2 shall be observed by everyone in Latvia in their daily routine - two meters, two people. So, a distance of two meters must be observed and meetings must be limited to two people.  Private events shall be prohibited, except than within a single household. It is allowed to visit people who live alone and need care, observing the 2 + 2 principle.  At funerals and christening ceremonies held in urgent cases, no more than 10 people (excluding those directly involved, such as the clergy) may gather outdoors, from no more than two households, using mouth and nose covers.

It is allowed to enter Latvia, provided that the guidelines developed by the Centre for Disease Prevention and Control (SPKC) are being followed. When arriving from countries with a 14-day cumulative number of COVID-19 cases that is higher than 50 per 100,000 inhabitants, self-isolation must be observed for 10 days.  10-day self-isolation must be observed when entering Latvia from the countries listed in the “National COVID-19 morbidity rates” section of the SPKC website.  If a person is arriving from a “safe” country by transiting through an “unsafe country”, the person must observe self-isolation; in order to avoid self-isolation, a different return route must be chosen.  Self-isolation means staying in the place of self-isolation without exposing other persons to the risk of infection and without making direct contact with others (not receiving guests, not visiting anyone, not going to work or public places where many people may be present, except for going to the shop or getting to the place of residence or of self-isolation immediately after arriving in Latvia, using a mouth and nose covering).  https://web.archive.org/web/20201207042737/https://covid19.gov.lv/en/covid-19-frequently-asked-questions-and-answers
No change to previous policy.

Downtime allowance and allowance for employee salary subsidies will be available to entrepreneurs in all sectors. The support will be available for the period from 9 November 2020 to 31 December 2020. The Cabinet of Ministers on Nov 24th, has decided that the above-mentioned types of aid will be available to taxpayers affected by the Covid-19 restrictive measures in all sectors.   http://web.archive.org/web/20201207043641/https://www.mk.gov.lv/en/aktualitates/vitenbergs-downtime-allowance-and-allowance-employee-salary-subsidies-will-be-available

No changes to the policy (ends on Dec31st).   On November 3rd the government decided to introduce downtime allowance of around 70% of the monthly pay for workers affected by Covid-19 (the difference with spring is that any company (in all economic sectors) can now apply for the allowance if it’s fall in revenue exceeds 20%). Allowance is paid to a merchant in the amount of 70% of the merchant’s declared average salary for three months (August, September, October). The subsidy will be paid to the employee (employed, self-employed, and patent payers). The minimum amount of the subsidy is planned to be EUR 330 (the amount is determined in accordance with the net minimum wage in the country); it is planned to pay another EUR 50 for each dependent; the maximum amount of the subsidy is EUR 1000 (net). At the same time, it is stipulated that the aid paid to employees must not exceed 80% of gross salary.   http://web.archive.org/web/20201207043641/https://www.mk.gov.lv/en/aktualitates/vitenbergs-downtime-allowance-and-allowance-employee-salary-subsidies-will-be-available

Measures for households and firms were announced centrally by the Finance Latvia association. The deadline to apply for these reliefs ended as of September 30. Legislative moratorium (announced by government) is viable only for student loans. As of now, even with new EBA guidelines announced last week, there are no new centralized programmes to apply.

No new changes. The National Extraordinary Public Health Commission (CNESP) emergency state in the public health sector all over Moldova continues through the period 30 November 2020 – 15 January 2021.

No policy changes for this time period, further restrictions will be in effect from 21 December for winter break activities from Decision No 37 of Moldova's National Extraordinary Public Health Commission from 11 December 2020, excerpt:  1. The following things are established, in order to boost the measures of prevention and control of the COVID-19 infection in the general secondary education institutions and the early education ones:    1.1. Carrying out of online classes at the education disciplines, according to the framework plan for the forms of the primary school, gymnasium and lyceum on the period 21-24 December 2020.    1.2. Suspension, starting from 14 December 2020, of the extracurricular activities (sports circles and sections) at the headquarters of the education institutions and their carrying out online.  1.3. The education activities on the occasion of the winter holidays in schools and kindergartens will be organized in classes/groups with the observance of the social distance, with the presence of only teachers/educators from the concerned class/group. The classes and groups will be provided with proper conditions for the hygiene/disinfection of hands.     1.4. The National Extraordinary Public Health Commission (CNESP) has ruled to establish emergency state in the public health sector all over Moldova on the period 30 November 2020 – 15 January 2021:  Ban the activity of night clubs (disco clubs, karaoke, disco pubs), starting from 28 November. At the same time, as of 30 November, the restaurants, pubs and coffee houses will be able to work till 22:00. The public nourishment units will be banned from working in the time interval 22:00-7:00.    The organization and holding of scientific conferences, sports competitions, Olympiads with the physical presence of people will be prohibited. Also, the presence of audience in theatres, movie theatres, concert halls and community centres will not be allowed.    At the same time, the public and private institutions will establish a special regime of work, with only the strictly necessary staff attracted to the working place, in order to ensure the enterprises’ functionality. The distance work will have to be organized for the personnel, whose activity does not need the compulsory presence at the working place.        https://web.archive.org/web/20201205215306/https://gov.md/en/content/national-extraordinary-public-health-commission-declares-state-emergency-public-health-all   https://web.archive.org/web/20201205214717/https://md.usembassy.gov/u-s-citizen-services/covid-19-information/

No new changes. The National Extraordinary Public Health Commission (CNESP) emergency state in the public health sector all over Moldova continues through the period 30 November 2020 – 15 January 2021.

On 8 December, additional restrictions on hours of some types of businesses were implemented:  The National Extraordinary Public Health Commission (CNESP) has ruled that, starting from today, the activity of servicing in all public nourishment units, including at those placed at the points for the sale of oil products, in commercial centres, airports, international ports, should be ceased at night, namely in the time interval 22:00-7:00.  Also, the (CNESP) members established that the public authorities subordinated to the government should work according to a special working regime, in the conditions of the pandemic situation in Moldova. Thus, the public sector employees will start their working day at 7:30 and will end it at 16:00, with a 30- minutes dinner break. The provision enters into force starting from 8 December and will be revised depending on the epidemiological situation.    https://web.archive.org/web/20201213221108/https://gov.md/en/content/moldovas-national-extraordinary-public-health-commission-rules-ban-service-public

Moldova joined COVAX in August 2020 and therefore, once vaccines are available it is expected that the following policy will be in place:  Thus, based on the fact that the Global Alliance for Vaccines and Immunizations, through the COVAX platform ensures coverage of 20% of the country's population free of charge, the following target groups have been identified: medical workers; adults over 65 years of age and comorbidities (high risk group); beneficiaries of temporary or long-term placement centers; people with comorbidities; social workers; workers in the field of education and those in security bodies.  Subsequently, depending on the availability of the vaccine, other groups of the population will be vaccinated, which are equally extremely important.    https://web.archive.org/web/20201213220911/https://www.gavi.org/sites/default/files/covid/pr/COVAX_CA_COIP_List_COVAX_PR_24-11.pdf  https://web.archive.org/web/20201213221805/https://en.publika.md/moldova-made-a-request-to-covax-platform-for-covid-19-vaccine--_2662393.html

"Extremely high risk" and "very high risk" counties:  - On business days, commercial establishments must close until 22:00. Restaurants, cultural facilities and sports facilities must close until 22:30 (catering establishments can operate until 01:00, but only for home deliveries).  - On weekends and holidays, commercial establishments can only operate between 08:00 and 13:00. - - The catering can work after that time, but only for 'take-away' and home deliveries.    "High risk" counties:  - Commercial establishments must close until 22:00. Restaurants, cultural facilities and sports facilities must close until 22:30 (catering establishments can operate until 01:00, but only for home deliveries).    "Moderate risk" counties  - Commercial establishments cannot open before 10:00 am, with the exception of hairdressers, barbers, beauty salons, restaurants and the like, cafeterias, tea houses and the like, driving schools and technical vehicle inspection centers, as well as gyms and gyms.  - Most commercial establishments are closed between 8 pm and 11 pm, and the closing time, within this interval, as well as the opening time, may be fixed by the mayors of the city councils, subject to a favorable opinion from the local health authority. and security forces.  - Restaurants have to close at 1:00 am (with new admissions until midnight), with their capacity limited to 50% of capacity. Groups are limited to six people (unless they belong to the same household), except in establishments located within 300 meters of a school and in the food courts of shopping centers, where they are limited to four people (if not from household).

Authorities in Portugal permit entry for travelers from the EU and Schengen Area countries, the UK, Australia, Canada, China, Georgia, Japan, New Zealand, Rwanda, South Korea, Thailand, Tunisia, and Uruguay; these arrivals do not require a COVID-19 test unless their final destination is the Azores or Madeira. Travel from other countries remains prohibited, except for limited essential reasons, including EU citizens and residents returning home, reuniting with family, and commuting to essential work or study. All such arrivals are required to submit a negative result from a COVID-19 test taken no more than 72 hours before boarding; however, Portuguese nationals and residents may arrange to take the test on arrival at their own expense.    Link: https://web.archive.org/web/20201213000026/https://www.garda.com/crisis24/news-alerts/409031/portugal-authorities-extend-state-of-emergency-through-dec-23-amid-ongoing-covid-19-activity-update-22

The 2021 state budget adopted on November 26 foresees further support to the national health system, employment and incomes of households and firms. Key measures include:   (i) income support measures, such as temporary reduction of PIT withholdings (0.1 percent of GDP);   (ii) expanded subsidy for employment and resumption of activity (0.5 percent of GDP) and extended support for workers' lost income and coverage for those without access to unemployment protection (0.2 percent of GDP);   (iii) staff reinforcement in the civil service, particularly in health and education (0.1 percent of GDP) and an extraordinary risk subsidy in the amount of 20 percent of base salary for health professionals at the forefront of the response to COVID-19; and   (iv) VAT tax rebate to stimulate consumption in the catering sectors, accommodation and culture by returning the VAT paid on consumption in these sectors (0.1 percent GDP).

The Government presented yesterday, December 3, the Vaccination Plan against Covid-19. According to the document, the vaccine, which should arrive in Portugal as early as January, will be universal, free and optional, and will be made available to the population according to the characteristics approved by the European Medicines Agency. Three phases are planned for the implementation of the vaccination plan against Covid-19 in 2021, which will accompany the pace of availability of vaccines.    1st phase - It is intended for people over 50 with associated pathologies; residents and professionals in nursing homes and long-term care units; Health professionals; armed forces, security forces and critical services professionals. At this stage, approximately 950 thousand people should be vaccinated.    2nd phase - In this phase 1.8 million people over 65 years of age and around 900 thousand with associated pathologies and over 50 years will be vaccinated.    3rd phase - The rest of the population. The groups in this phase will be reviewed according to the pace of delivery of the vaccines    Vaccine administration  The first phase of vaccination will be administered at the approximately 1,200 vaccination points that are usual in health centers, in homes and long-term care units.  The health centers will be destined to 400 thousand people over 50 years old and associated comorbidities, while users and home professionals will be vaccinated there by the resident nursing teams.  The vaccine will also be administered to health professionals and essential services in the field of occupational medicine.  Link: https://web.archive.org/web/20201213003729/https://www.sns.gov.pt/noticias/2020/12/04/plano-de-vacinacao-contra-a-covid-19/

According to the ministerial order 5972/8.11.20, the teaching activities that require the physical presence of preschoolers and students in preschool, primary, secondary, high school and post-secondary education units are suspended for a period of 30 days. The teaching activities will be carried out online, according to the Framework Methodology on conducting teaching activities through technology and the Internet, as well as for the processing of personal data, approved by order of the Ministry of Education and Research 5545/2020.  Links: https://archive.fo/7GMr0

According to the Decision 52/5.11.2020 of The National Emergency Committee, the activity of food markets in closed spaces, fairs, mixed, flying and flea markets will be forbidden. Also, for the economic operators having activities in closed and/or open spaces, (public or private) to organize their activity only between 05:00 and 21:00. According to the Decision 52/5.11.2020 of The National Emergency Committee, it is in place the obligation to wear a protective mask, to cover the nose and mouth, for all persons who have reached the age of 5, in all open and closed public spaces. Also, to avoid the congestion of public transport, it is proposed to all public institutions and all economic operators to organize work schedule (where telework is not possible) into at least two groups to start/finish the activity at a difference of at least two hours.  Link: https://s.iw.ro/gateway/g/ZmlsZVNvdXJjZT1odHRwJTNBJTJGJTJG/c3RvcmFnZTA2dHJhbnNjb2Rlci5yY3Mt/cmRzLnJvJTJGc3RvcmFnZSUyRjIwMjAl/MkYxMSUyRjA2JTJGMTI0ODQ3NV8xMjQ4/NDc1X0hvdGFyYXJlLUNOU1UtNTItZGlu/LTA1XzExXzIwMjAtdjE5LTEucGRmJmhh/c2g9NjkxN2E0NDIwOTQ4MGQ1NjJiYzMxZmNjYjczZjY2NjI=.pdf

The Ministry of Interior published the list of quarantined localities. Also, the Ministry of Health published the recommendations for preventing the spread of coronavirus (working from home where it is possible, people should avoid crowded areas and limit to the maximum any direct contact with other people, other than those who are part of the same family). Also, according to the Decision 52/5.11.2020 of The National Emergency Committee, in all localities in Romania, it is in place a ban for traffic persons outside the home between 23:00 and 5:00 (exception for travel in professional interest, for medical assistance). On 20th of November, The National Committee for Emergency Situations published Decision no.55 regarding the approval of the list of countries/areas of epidemiological risk for which the quarantine measure is instituted on persons arriving in Romania from them. Also, there are screening procedures implemented at the “Henri Coanda” International Airport (three thermal scanners and a joint action plan with the Border Police and the Public Health Directorate to collect questionnaires from travelers arriving in the country and to distribute information about local measures and restrictions).    Link: https://archive.fo/9KkOQ and https://archive.fo/lIjB1

On 20th of November, The National Committee for Emergency Situations published Decision no.55 regarding the approval of the list of countries/areas of epidemiological risk for which the quarantine measure is instituted on persons arriving in Romania from them. Also, there are screening procedures implemented at the “Henri Coanda” International Airport (three thermal scanners and a joint action plan with the Border Police and the Public Health Directorate to collect questionnaires from travelers arriving in the country and to distribute information about local measures and restrictions).  According to the Decision 56/4.12.2020 of The National Committee for Emergency Situations, the list of countries of high epidemiological risk for which the quarantine measure is instituted on the persons arriving in Romania from them was approved.  Link: https://archive.fo/9KkOQ, https://archive.fo/lIjB1, https://archive.fo/pUara and https://archive.fo/s1GX6

The measures introduced by GEO 30/2020 include:   1.	The criteria for sending employees into technical unemployment and minimum income ensured for freelancers working in industries where activity is reduced or interrupted due to the pandemic.  2.	The conditions for granting free paid days to parents, to supervise their children during the temporary closure of educational establishments.  3.	The online submission of the documentation needed to gain access to social benefits.  4.	The measures for ensuring continuity in the granting of return to work incentives and childcare allowance, as well as for facilitating access to medical leave and medical leave indemnities for quarantined persons.    Link: https://archive.fo/FtT0q

On 22nd of October, the government approved the application of the simplified alternative procedure for granting payment rescheduling for a maximum of 12 months. Beneficiaries of the simplified staggering facility are all taxpayers.  According to Emergency Ordinance 69/14.05.2020, the authorities have adopted fiscal measures to help taxpayers overcome the problems caused by the COVID-19 pandemic (granting bonuses, extension of the deadline for submitting the Single Declaration, tax facilities for incentives and bonuses granted by the employer from the salary fund for the period of emergency to employees whose activity involves risk of infection with SARS-CoV-2, bonuses regarding the annual building tax and the monthly building tax, cancellation of ancillary payment obligations.  Link: https://archive.fo/OJIQT and https://archive.fo/hVM21

Ministry of Health published “Recommendations on responsible social behavior in preventing the spread of coronavirus (COVID-19)” and “Recommended measures to reduce the impact of the COVID-19 pandemic”. On 29th of October, The Government of Romania announced the List of infection diseases for which the isolation of persons is established at their home. The same document establishes the basic health units in which sick people can be treated with diseases provided in the list of infectious diseases. Also, “Datelazi.ro” (Updated data) project was released pro-bon by Code for Romania in partnership with the Government of Romania through the Authority for the Digitalization of Romania, containing data and information provided by the Government of Romania.   Links: https://archive.fo/cUlEp, https://archive.fo/klswT , https://archive.fo/Vi0vG and https://archive.fo/X428Q

According to the Ministry of Health, the units that are accredited by the Ministry of Health to perform the diagnosis by RT-PCR have the obligation to provide priority diagnosis for patients in health facilities, suspects in epidemiological investigations, and people at risk, according to the methodology of the National Institute of Public Health – National Center for Surveillance and Control of Communicable Diseases.   Link: https://archive.fo/6K5UM

An official document regarding contact tracing and testing of contacts of COVID-19 confirmed patient was released by National Center for Surveillance and Control of Transmissible Diseases on 23rd of July 2020. On 28th of October, the Ministry of Health published updated the flow of information used in reporting SARS CoV-2 virus infection data.  According to this document, the Directorates of Public Health (DSP) have the obligation to identify and confirm, following the epidemiological investigation, direct contacts of each person tested positive.   Link: https://archive.fo/thRdi and https://archive.fo/FUhtr

According to this document, the Directorates of Public Health (DSP) have the obligation to identify and confirm, following the epidemiological investigation, direct contacts of each person tested positive.   Link: https://archive.fo/thRdi and https://archive.fo/FUhtr

At the proposal of the Ministry of Health, the Government approved the Vaccination Strategy against SARA-CoV-2 in Romania. The document establishes the vision, principles and mode of action for the administration in Romania of COVID-19 vaccines authorized by the European Medicines Agency.  Link: https://archive.fo/wip/C61Wh

The Government approved the Vaccination Strategy against SARA-CoV-2 in Romania. The document establishes the vision, principles, and mode of action for the administration in Romania of COVID-19 vaccines authorized by the European Medicines Agency. Also, the chairman of the National Coordinating Committee for Vaccination Activities against COVID-19 announced that the National Vaccine Storage Center is ready to receive vaccines after the European Medicines Agency issues the conditional marketing authorization. There are three stages of vaccination: first for health care workers, second -for the population at risk, for essential staff and the last stage – for the general population.  Link: https://archive.fo/KYZQL and https://archive.fo/KYZQL

The Government approved the Vaccination Strategy against SARA-CoV-2 in Romania. The document establishes the vision, principles, and mode of action for the administration in Romania of COVID-19 vaccines authorized by the European Medicines Agency. Also, the chairman of the National Coordinating Committee for Vaccination Activities against COVID-19 announced that the National Vaccine Storage Center is ready to receive vaccines after the European Medicines Agency issues the conditional marketing authorization. There are three stages of vaccination: first for health care workers, second -for the population at risk, for essential staff and the last stage – for the general population.  Link: https://archive.fo/KYZQL and https://archive.fo/KYZQL

No new policy changes from 08 December.    On 18 December, the existing measures in place were extended until further notice.    https://web.archive.org/web/20201219180525/https://rs.usembassy.gov/serbia-covid-19-information/    https://web.archive.org/web/20201219180922/https://www.srbija.gov.rs/vest/en/165283/new-restrictive-measures-to-depend-on-epidemiological-situation.php

Further restrictions were introduced on 4 Dec, with a number of workplace sectors required to close on weekends (5 pm on Friday to 5 am on Monday). This includes restaurants, shopping centres, casinos, hair salons and sports facilities. All of the above are allowed to continue open between 5 am and 5 pm on weekdays. An exception is made to food delivery services, which are allowed to function 24/7.     "Grocery stores, shops, retail facilities, as well as newsagents, kiosks and the like, where, as a rule, customers do not enter the facility in order to make the purchase, can work on weekdays and weekends until 9 pm.    Pharmacies and gas stations (fuel sales) can work non-stop, every day without restrictions.    Open-air green markets will also work on weekends from 6 am. to 3 pm."    "Medical centres and laboratories can operate throughout the day, including weekends."    http://web.archive.org/web/20201207201946/https://www.srbija.gov.rs/vest/en/164342/tighter-anti-coronavirus-measures-in-effect-as-of-tomorrow.php

On 04 December, State Secretary of the Ministry of Health Mirsad Djerlek stated today that mass vaccination in Serbia is expected in the first quarter of 2021, and that a certain amount of vaccines will arrive by the end of 2020.    https://web.archive.org/web/20201219184423/https://www.srbija.gov.rs/vest/en/164417/mass-vaccination-in-first-quarter-of-2021.php

On 18 December, Minister of Health Zoran Loncar stated today in Novi Sad that the first doses of Pfizer vaccine will arrive in Serbia on Monday or Tuesday, adding that slightly less than 5,000 doses will arrive in the first tranche and that they will be received by users of nursing homes.    https://web.archive.org/web/20201219183423/https://www.srbija.gov.rs/vest/en/165232/first-doses-of-pfizer-vaccine-in-serbia-on-monday.php

No changes in school policy until 07 December, when primary and secondary schools will be able to re-open if they can implement rapid testing.    https://web.archive.org/web/20201205231538/https://www.uvzsr.sk/docs/info/ut/ciastka_20_2020.pdf  https://web.archive.org/web/20201205232259/https://korona.gov.sk/

With effect from 7 December 2020, where the operating conditions so permit and if the founder so decides:  resumes school teaching in primary schools in the fifth to ninth grades, secondary schools, primary arts schools and language schools for pupils and listeners who fulfil the conditions set out in point B.1. resolutions of the Government of the Slovak Republic No. 760 of 4 December 2020 and in decree of the Public Health Office of the Slovak Republic No. 32/2020 V. v. SR ordering measures at risk of public health to prove negative results of the test for COVID-19 disease before entering the premises of schools, and restore the operation of school facilities for pupils as referred to in point 1.    https://web.archive.org/web/20201214004111/https://korona.gov.sk/obnova-vyucovania-na-skolach-od-11-12-2020/
No change.

No change in policy since November’s extension of the state of emergency, restrictions are expected to continue through the end of the year.    https://web.archive.org/web/20201205232259/https://korona.gov.sk/  https://web.archive.org/web/20201205231632/https://sk.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

From 11 December, the Slovak Republic will enter a lockdown additional restrictions will be in place for some sectors:  December 11, 2020: the outdoor terraces of restaurants, cafés and similar facilities will be closed. Takeaways should be preserved. Driving schools will switch to remote classes.  December 14, 2020: stricter conditions will be implemented for hotels and ski centres: every visitor older than 10 years of age will be required to show a negative rapid or PCR test result no older than 72 hours.  In hotels, it will not be possible to eat and drink in the shared spaces.  In terms of ski lifts, only one person or people from the same household will be allowed to be on one chairlift or in one cable car.  December 21, 2020: School holiday begins and shops except for essential ones (grocery stores etc.) will be closed. The shops will stay closed for three weeks in each district, i.e. at least until January 10. It is not clear yet when schools will reopen.  December 28, 2020: Regular testing in companies with more than 500 employees will begin, so that they can return to work.  No curfew or mobility restrictions will be applied during the lockdown.  The restrictions will be lifted in those areas where the epidemic situation allows it.     https://web.archive.org/web/20201214004241/https://www.uvzsr.sk/index.php?option=com_content&view=category&layout=blog&id=223&Itemid=144  https://web.archive.org/web/20201214004530/https://spectator.sme.sk/c/22551152/the-central-crisis-staff-agreed-on-lockdown.html?ref=av-center
No change.

No change in overall policy, but a small change to one of the Public Health Agency's recommendations: when someone in the family has been tested positive, even asymptomatic pre-school and primary school children have to stay home. This recommendation only applied to older children before.

From 7 December until 6 January, high schools will be closed. On 3 December, the Public Health Agency issued a 'recommendation' to close all high schools (gymnasieskolor - ages 16-19) for a month and move all classes online. This dose not include exams which cannot be taken at a distance.     In line with the Interpretation Guide on C1, I have coded this as '2', since "if the situation is that all schools are closed ... then that would count as a full closure".    http://web.archive.org/web/20201207153005/https://www.folkhalsomyndigheten.se/contentassets/27a3b8becacc47edbfa51273b4931886/beslut-2020-12-03-rekommendation-om-delvis-stangning-och-overgang-till-fjarr-eller-distansundervisning-gymnasieskolan.pdf  http://web.archive.org/web/20201207154159/https://www.skolverket.se/regler-och-ansvar/coronaviruset-och-covid-19---regler-for-skolor-och-forskolor/regler-for-forskolor-och-skolor-som-ar-oppna-stangda-eller-varit-stangda-under-coronapandemin

On 24 Nov, a new ban on public gatherings of over 8 people came into effect. This does not apply to most workplaces, but does affect some sectors to the point where they are required to close, such as amusement parks, markets and fairs. For theaters and cinemas, the official rule is that seated audiences of up to 300 are allowed as long as social distancing measures are adhered to, although the reality on the ground is much stricter as the regions have issued non-binding recommendations which extend the 8-people limit to seated audiences.     http://web.archive.org/web/20201207171245/https://www.krisinformation.se/en/hazards-and-risks/disasters-and-incidents/2020/official-information-on-the-new-coronavirus/restriktioner-och-forbud
No change in policy

No change in policy since last entry: https://web.archive.org/web/20201221201555/https://www.krisinformation.se/en/hazards-and-risks/disasters-and-incidents/2020/official-information-on-the-new-coronavirus/restriktioner-och-forbud

There is a ban on public gatherings of over 8 people. Technically the exception for seated audiences of up to 300 (as long as social distancing measures are adhered to) remains in place, but the reality on the ground is much stricter as the regions have issued non-binding recommendations which extend the 8-people limit to seated audiences.     http://web.archive.org/web/20201207171245/https://www.krisinformation.se/en/hazards-and-risks/disasters-and-incidents/2020/official-information-on-the-new-coronavirus/restriktioner-och-forbud

There is a ban on public gatherings of over 8 people (in force since 24 Nov), which means it is impossible to hold public events.     https://web.archive.org/web/20201214164126/https://www.krisinformation.se/en/hazards-and-risks/disasters-and-incidents/2020/official-information-on-the-new-coronavirus/restriktioner-och-forbud

There is a ban on public gatherings of over 8 people.    See eg: https://web.archive.org/web/20201130183955/https://www.thelocal.se/20201116/breaking-sweden-introduces-limit-of-eight-coronavirus

For public gatherings, there is a ban on gatherings over 8 people. The Public Health Agency "strongly recommends" to also adhere to these requirements in private.     https://web.archive.org/web/20201214164126/https://www.krisinformation.se/en/hazards-and-risks/disasters-and-incidents/2020/official-information-on-the-new-coronavirus/restriktioner-och-forbud    In the words of home minister Mikael Damberg: "The recommendations from the agencies aren't some kind of tips for the public -- they should be followed."    https://web.archive.org/web/20201214162622/https://www.thelocal.se/20201211/sweden-to-send-mass-text-banging-home-christmas-covid-rules

In force from 14 December, the Public Health Agency replaced its regional advice with national regulations and general advice, in light of the upcoming Christmas holidays. This includes the recommendation to limit the number of encounters and spend time in a "small circle" and avoid being part of several different groups, in order to reduce the number of close contacts as much as possible. "The fewer, the better." A smaller circle ["mindre krets"] is "a few people, but it is not possible to say an exact number. Who and how many are included in the circle can vary based on each individual's life situation. For some it may be some close friends, for others the immediate family."    https://web.archive.org/web/20201214164556/https://www.folkhalsomyndigheten.se/smittskydd-beredskap/utbrott/aktuella-utbrott/covid-19/skydda-dig-och-andra/jul-och-andra-hogtider/

No change: public transportation is operating but services may be limited, both as regards the number of passengers allowed and frequency of departures.     http://web.archive.org/web/20201207171523/https://www.krisinformation.se/en/hazards-and-risks/disasters-and-incidents/2020/official-information-on-the-new-coronavirus/domestic-travel-and-public-transport

Public transport operates at reduced capacity, has reduced the number of bookable seats and recommends using a different means of transport if there are no more bookable seats available for a specific departure time.     https://web.archive.org/web/20201214165754/https://www.sj.se/sv/om/om-sj/senaste-info-coronavirus-o-tagresor.html    https://web.archive.org/web/20201214165848/https://www.trafikverket.se/om-oss/var-verksamhet/sa-har-jobbar-vi-med/trafikverkets-forhallningssatt-till-coronaviruset/

In force from 14 December, the Public Health Agency replaced its regional advice with national regulations and general advice, in light of the upcoming Christmas holidays. These are divided into rules and advice aimed at individuals, with an emphasis on personal responsibility, and rules and advice aimed at businesses. Re public transport, for individuals, the recommendation is to limit the use of public transport as much as possible. Public transport companies should: 1) run schedules in such a way as to reduce the risk of congestion; 2) limit the number of passengers per vehicle; 3) inform their passengers on how they can reduce the risk of spreading the virus.    https://web.archive.org/web/20201214164556/https://www.folkhalsomyndigheten.se/smittskydd-beredskap/utbrott/aktuella-utbrott/covid-19/skydda-dig-och-andra/jul-och-andra-hogtider/
No change in policy, but the wording of the Public Health Agency in its recommendations has gradually become more urgent, especially in the regional recommendations.
No change in policy since last entry

There is currently no regulation that requires the use of facemasks, but the Public Health Agency has announced that it will produce a national guideline on the use of facemasks in public transport on weekdays before 7 January 2021, when most people return to work or school after the holidays.     The public transport providers will need to inform travelers about the recommendation to use facemasks and should provide facemasks free of charge for those travellers who do not bring their own.     http://web.archive.org/web/20201221201620/https://www.folkhalsomyndigheten.se/nyheter-och-press/nyhetsarkiv/2020/december/ytterligare-atgarder-for-att-bromsa-smitta-och-skydda-halsa/

Schools are open, but the government continues to implement social-distancing and hygiene measures at schools. It should also be noted that the Turkmenistan government still insists the country is coronavirus-free.     http://web-old.archive.org/web/20201117033257/https://www.japantimes.co.jp/news/2020/11/12/world/last-pandemic-free-places/    http://web-old.archive.org/web/20201208051714/https://tm.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/
No changes found from last announcements.

There has been no significant change since the last data entry. The government continues to require many business activities to remain closed. It should also be noted that the Turkmenistan government still insists "no cases of coronavirus infection have been registered in the country to date."    Grocery stores are open. However, "[m]any stores, shopping malls, and restaurants are closed or have limited operations."    "Recreational facilities, non-essential shops, bars and restaurants, entertainment facilities, sports, spa and beauty facilities, and mosques are closed to the public."    http://web-old.archive.org/web/20201208051714/https://tm.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/    http://web-old.archive.org/web/20201208052008/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/turkmenistan/coronavirus
No changes found from last announcements.

The government continues to cancel public events. It should also be noted that the Turkmenistan government still insists "no cases of coronavirus infection have been registered in the country to date."    "Recreational facilities, non-essential shops, bars and restaurants, entertainment facilities, sports, spa and beauty facilities, and mosques are closed to the public."    "Mosques and places of pilgrimage are closed and large gatherings are restricted."    http://web-old.archive.org/web/20201208051714/https://tm.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/    http://web-old.archive.org/web/20201208052008/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/turkmenistan/coronavirus
No changes found from last announcements.

The government continues to impose measures to restrict large gatherings. But the cap on the number of people is not clear.  It should also be noted that the Turkmenistan government still insists the country is coronavirus-free.     "Mosques and places of pilgrimage are closed and large gatherings are restricted."    http://web-old.archive.org/web/20201208052008/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/turkmenistan/coronavirus    http://web-old.archive.org/web/20201208051714/https://tm.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/
No changes found from last announcements.

The government continues to limit the services of public transport. It should also be noted that the Turkmenistan government still insists "no cases of coronavirus infection have been registered in the country to date."    "Traffic police check points have been established around major population centres, including Ashgabat, and road users may be subject to temperature screening."    "[N]ewspapers report that a COVID-19 test result is required for boarding domestic flights."    "Domestic flights remain operational, but with a reduced service. Passengers are subject to temperature checks."    "Rail services are suspended."    http://web-old.archive.org/web/20201208052008/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/turkmenistan/coronavirus    http://web-old.archive.org/web/20201208051714/https://tm.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/
No changes found from last announcements.

There has been no significant change since the last date input. The government continues to not require people to stay at home. There are rumours that a lockdown might have been introduced since 1 November 2020, but the source is unofficial and cannot be confirmed. It should also be noted that the Turkmenistan government still insists "no cases of coronavirus infection have been registered in the country to date."    http://web-old.archive.org/web/20201116183946/https://for.kg/news-674059-en.html    https://www.barrons.com/news/turkmen-leader-opens-new-hospital-insists-country-virus-free-01605340808
No changes found from last announcements.

The government continues to restrict internal movement. It should also be noted that the Turkmenistan government still insists "no cases of coronavirus infection have been registered in the country to date."    "Traffic police check points have been established around major population centres, including Ashgabat, and road users may be subject to temperature screening."    "Domestic flights remain operational, but with a reduced service. Passengers are subject to temperature checks."    "[N]ewspapers report that a COVID-19 test result is required for boarding domestic flights."    "Rail services are suspended."    "Are there restrictions on intercity or interstate travel? Yes. There are some reports of restrictions on interstate travel."    http://web-old.archive.org/web/20201208051714/https://tm.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/    http://web-old.archive.org/web/20201208052008/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/turkmenistan/coronavirus
No changes found from last announcements.

The government continues to close its border. It should also be noted that the Turkmenistan government still insists "no cases of coronavirus infection have been registered in the country to date."    "All international commercial flights to and from Turkmenistan have been cancelled and land borders are closed to passenger traffic. Some press reporting indicates that international flight restrictions are expected to continue through January 1, 2020."    "Commercial flights to and from Turkmenistan are suspended. Occasional, tightly controlled, charter flights are the only means of entering or leaving the country by air."    http://web-old.archive.org/web/20201208052008/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/turkmenistan/coronavirus    http://web-old.archive.org/web/20201208051714/https://tm.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/
No changes found from last announcements.
The government continues to not offer any income support.
No changes found from last announcements.
The government continues to not offer any debt/contract relief.
No changes found from last announcements.

The government continues to deny the existence of any COVID case in the country, but there are coordinated public information campaigns in place.     "The Government of Turkmenistan’s Ministry of Health has established a COVID-19 hotline (tel. +993 12 73 9535) where citizens may receive information about the virus, including prevention and treatment, in both Russian and Turkmen languages."    http://web-old.archive.org/web/20201208051714/https://tm.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/
No changes found from last announcements.

The government continues to not implement any testing policy since it continues to deny the presence of COVID in the country. However, according to the US Embassy in Turkmenistan, "COVID-19 testing is offered in Ashgabat at Jemgyyetcilik Saglygy we Iymit Merkezi (the Virology Laboratory of the Public Health and Nutrition Center) on Gorgoly 84, Ashgabat. The test costs 100 manat for citizens of Turkmenistan and $43 for foreign citizens." Whether citizens of Turkmenistan can actually access the COVID test is unclear.    http://web-old.archive.org/web/20201208051714/https://tm.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/
No changes found from last announcements.

The government continues to not implement any contact tracing measures. It should also be noted that the Turkmenistan government still insists "no cases of coronavirus infection have been registered in the country to date."    http://web-old.archive.org/web/20201116182822/https://www.barrons.com/news/turkmen-leader-opens-new-hospital-insists-country-virus-free-01605340808
No changes found from last announcements.

The government continues to require people to wear masks in public spaces. It should also be noted that the Turkmenistan government still insists "no cases of coronavirus infection have been registered in the country to date."    "Masks are required in most public places, including public transit."    "It is compulsory to wear a facemask when in public."    http://web-old.archive.org/web/20201208052008/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/turkmenistan/coronavirus    http://web-old.archive.org/web/20201208051714/https://tm.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/
No changes found from last announcements.

From 19 December 2020, new restrictions will apply throughout Ukraine.   Acc. to these new restrictions it is forbidden:  - Carrying out mass events (performances, holiday concerts) in educational institutions with the participation of children from more than one group/class and in the presence of visitors.  - Carrying out festive events, banquets, master classes, public events in public catering establishments and entertainment facilities.  - Reception of visitors in museums, exhibitions, galleries if there are more than 1 visitor per 10m2.  - Operation of public catering establishments from 22:00 to 7:00 (except for delivery of takeaway orders). Payment transactions are prohibited after 22:00. During the night of December 31– January 1 the work of restaurants and cafes will be allowed until 01:00.  - Conducting religious events indoors upon condition that there will be present more than 1 person per 5 square meters; religious events open-air not keeping the requirement of maintaining physical distance 1.5 meters between those present.    Restrictions that continue to be in force (what is still forbidden):  • Staying in transport and public places without a mask, being outside without documents. • Unauthorized leave of the observation place. • Carrying out of mass cultural, sports, social, advertising and other actions in which more than 20 persons take part and not preserving physical distance 1.5 meters between participants (with some exceptions). • Operation of cinemas and cultural facilities with more than 50% occupancy per hall. • Carriage of more passengers in passenger transport than the number of seats (except metro). • Work of discos, night clubs and operation of public catering establishments with the organization of leisure. • Not abiding the demand to preserve a physical distance of 2 meters between the tables and to place a maximum number of 4 people at one table. • The work of business entities in which employees are not provided with masks, no markings are applied to the distance of 1.5 meters between customers, and visitors not properly wearing personal protective equipment. • Crossing the border for foreigners without an existing insurance policy (with some exceptions). • Activities of accommodation facilities (except hotels). • Visiting by a group of more than 20 persons of educational institutions, except for preschool, general secondary, out-of-school and specialized education institutions. • Visiting preschool, general secondary, out-of-school, sports and art education institutions when more than 50% of students and staff of the educational institution stay in self-isolation. • Carrying out planned hospitalization (with exceptions). • Operation of gyms, fitness centers and museums, if they allow more than 1 person per 20 m2. • Visiting places of temporary detention of persons, places of temporary stay of foreigners and stateless persons, accommodation places for refugees. • Crossing the checkpoints with the temporarily occupied territories of separate areas of Donetsk and Luhansk regions (ORDLO) and Crimea by foreigners without an existing insurance policy (with some exceptions). • Visits to social protection institutions with the stay of persons of certain categories (persons of senior age, war veterans, people with disabilities, mental disorders, etc.).    https://web.archive.org/web/20201220102241/https://www.kmu.gov.ua/en/news/uryadom-zaprovadzheno-perelik-karantinnih-obmezhen-yaki-diyatimut-z-19-grudnya-2020-roku-na-vsij-teritoriyi-ukrayini
